p:
In the second set of temperature regimes (future; T
mean varied from 15.0°C to 30.0°C and T
range varied from 0.0°C to 15.0°C, both in increments of 0.2°C), epidemic peak time and size show similar inverse variation as a function of starting temperature, although the overall behavior is different. Epidemic peak size had a unimodal distribution with its peak at ~28 °C and steadily declines afterward. Conversely the time to peak starts to increase at ~17 °C to ~19 °C, then steadily decreases until ~28 °C. At this peak of ~28 °C, the epidemic peak size was at 19% of the susceptible population infected, within a short peak time of 73 days. On the other hand, the final epidemic size steeply increases as a function of starting temperature, and plateaus at ~21 °C to ~30 °C (with 100% of the population infected), before steeply declining ( Fig 4B). Extending the temperature regimes demonstrates the nonlinear influence of the interaction between mean temperature and seasonal variance on the epidemic dynamics.
